text: I'm not sure what you're trying to achieve, but dynamically getting the unit from the string is probably not possible via the string macro

elements.text: I'm not sure what you're trying to achieve, but dynamically getting the unit from the string is probably not possible via the string macro

text: string macros only operate on strings

elements.text: string macros only operate on strings

unit

text:
I'm reading in a binary filetype and to do this I have Python code already that reads these files.. in the module it has a dictionary to look up and figure out what the fields unit type should be.. this function outputs a string...

I am using PyCall to call the Python code and make my own Julia loader.. and I wanted to have everything in a real unit type..

text: A very quick and dirty way is to use `@eval @u_str $unit`, but this will generally be inefficient.

elements.text: A very quick and dirty way is to use
@eval @u_str $unit
, but this will generally be inefficient.

text:
ahh ok.. thanks.. i was trying to see which function the macro calls but its not ..
```macro u_str(unit)
    ex = Meta.parse(unit)
    esc(replace_value(__module__, ex))
end```

elements.text: ahh ok.. thanks.. i was trying to see which function the macro calls but its not ..

macro u_str(unit)
    ex = Meta.parse(unit)
    esc(replace_value(__module__, ex))
end

text:
You could do something like
```lookup_unit(s) = get!(() -> @eval(@u_str $s), unit_dict, s)```
where `unit_dict` would be a global dict.

elements.text: You could do something like
lookup_unit(s) = get!(() -> @eval(@u_str $s), unit_dict, s)
where
unit_dict
would be a global dict.

text: That way, you wouldn't have to use `eval` multiple times for the same unit

elements.text: That way, you wouldn't have to use
eval
multiple times for the same unit

Nice. 10 U.S. furlongs multiplied with 1e-9 Jupiter Radius is 143.81931419862838 m².
